alerts.headline: squall warning in effect
alerts.description:
Squalls with wind gusts up to 40 knots, frequent lightning and poor to very poor visibility in thunderstorms heavy at times are expected or occurring in the area.

Thunderstorms continue to move east across the waters to the shore from Wawa to Batchawana Bay.

###

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
alerts.instruction: Mariners are advised to prepare for squalls. If underway, seek safe harbour immediately. Consider delaying or postponing travel in areas under the squall warning. If you must travel, keep others informed of your planned route and carry appropriate safety equipment including a GPS and satellite phone or marine radio.

alerts.headline: squall warning in effect
alerts.description:

###

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

alerts.headline: rainfall warning in effect
alerts.description:
Rain, at times heavy, is expected.

What:
Additional rainfall amounts of 30 to 60 mm.
Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 100 mm over a few areas.

When:
Tonight.

Additional information:
Radar estimates indicate that 25 to 50 mm of rain fell during two rounds of showers and thunderstorms earlier today. More thunderstorms are tracking east across the region.  Significant rainfall is likely, especially for areas that receive multiple rounds of thunderstorms.

For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details.

###

Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy rainfall in combination with other weather factors, such as hail, wind and lightning will make outdoor activities unsafe.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.

alerts.headline: squall watch in effect
alerts.description:
Conditions are favourable for the development of squalls with wind gusts up to 40 knots, frequent lightning and poor to very poor visibility in thunderstorms heavy at times.

###

Poor to very poor visibility may contribute to voyage delays and make marine navigation hazardous.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
alerts.instruction: Mariners are advised to prepare for potential squalls. Vulnerable vessels are most at risk and should seek safe harbour if underway.

alerts.headline: squall watch in effect
alerts.description:
Conditions are favourable for the development of squalls with wind gusts up to 40 knots, frequent lightning and poor to very poor visibility in thunderstorms heavy at times.

Thunderstorms will move eastward across the lake tonight and reach the shore in locations from near Michipicoten to near Montreal River Harbour.

###

Poor to very poor visibility may contribute to voyage delays and make marine navigation hazardous.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
alerts.instruction: Mariners are advised to prepare for potential squalls. Vulnerable vessels are most at risk and should seek safe harbour if underway.

alerts.headline: fog advisory in effect
alerts.description:
Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring.

Fog banks from Lake Superior will affect the area for the rest of tonight. Conditions may slowly improve beginning Wednesday morning.

###

Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: If travelling, be prepared for areas of near-zero visibility. If visibility is reduced while driving, turn on your lights and maintain a safe following distance.

alerts.headline: rainfall warning in effect
alerts.description:
Rain, at times heavy, is expected.

What:
Additional rainfall amounts of 30 to 60 mm.
Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 100 mm over a few areas.

When:
Tonight into Wednesday.

Additional information:
Radar estimates indicate that 25 to 50 mm of rain fell during two rounds of showers and thunderstorms Tuesday. More showers and  thunderstorms are tracking east across the region.  Significant rainfall is likely, especially for areas that receive multiple rounds of heavy showers and thunderstorms.

For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details.

###

Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Heavy rainfall in combination with other weather factors, such as hail, wind and lightning will make outdoor activities unsafe.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or post reports on X using #ONStorm.
alerts.instruction: Watch for possible washouts near rivers, creeks and culverts.

alerts.headline: severe thunderstorm watch ended
alerts.description:
Conditions are no longer favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms.


###

alerts.headline: severe thunderstorm watch ended
alerts.description:
Conditions are no longer favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms.


###

affected_areas.area_description: Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay

alerts.headline: special air quality statement in effect
alerts.description:
Elevated pollution levels are expected to continue late evening. 

A special air quality statement is in place due to the possibility of deteriorating air quality. Weather conditions are expected to cause increasing levels of ozone. Moderate risk AQHI values are expected through late this evening with the potential of short-term high risk AQHI values as a result of ozone combining with residual smoke.

The high pollutant levels are expected to diminish overnight.

###

When air pollution levels are high, everyone should limit time outdoors. Consider reducing or rescheduling outdoor sports, activities and events.

You may experience mild and common symptoms such as eye, nose and throat irritation, headaches or a mild cough. More serious but less common symptoms include wheezing, chest pains or severe cough. If you think you are having a medical emergency, seek immediate medical assistance.

People more likely to be impacted by outdoor air pollution, including people aged 65 and older, pregnant people, infants and young children, people with an existing illness or chronic health condition, and people who work outdoors, should reduce or reschedule strenuous activities outdoors and seek medical attention if experiencing symptoms.

Visit http://www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
alerts.instruction:
When indoors, keep windows and doors closed as much as possible. When there is an extreme heat event occurring with poor air quality, prioritize keeping cool.

Protect your indoor air from outdoor air pollution. Actions can include using a clean, good quality air filter in your ventilation system and/or a certified portable air cleaner.

Check in on others who are in your care or live nearby who may be more likely to be impacted by outdoor air pollution.

Always follow guidance from local authorities.

affected_areas.area_description: Watford - Pinery Park - Eastern Lambton County
St. Catharines - Grimsby - Northern Niagara Region
